conclusion: Understanding the relationship between acceleration and velocity.
Area under acceleration-time graph gives change in velocity.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, acceleration is constant at 2 m/s².
From t = 1 to t = 3 seconds, acceleration decreases from 2 m/s² to -2 m/s².
From t = 3 to t = 4 seconds, acceleration is constant at -2 m/s².
Initial velocity v₀ is zero as the object starts from rest.
Velocity at t = 1 s is 2 m/s by integrating acceleration from 0 to 1.
Calculate change in velocity from t = 1 to t = 3 using area under graph.
Area under graph from t = 1 to t = 3 is 0 m/s, so velocity at t = 3 is 2 m/s.
Velocity at t = 4 s is 0 m/s by integrating acceleration from 3 to 4.
Velocity is 0 m/s at t = 0, 2 m/s at t = 1, 2 m/s at t = 3, and 0 m/s at t = 4.
Velocity reaches maximum value of 2 m/s at t = 1 s and t = 3 s.
Velocity increases from 0 to 2 m/s from t = 0 to t = 1 s.
Velocity remains constant at 2 m/s from t = 1 to t = 3 s.
